Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Patient-Reported Symptomatic Adverse Events in Neoadjuvant Therapy for Borderline Resectable Pancreatic Cancer

Trial_Design.evidence: patients with borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma were randomised to receive either 8 doses of mFOLFIRINOX (Arm 1) or 7 doses of mFOLFIRINOX plus hypofractionated radiotherapy (Arm 2)

Participants.evidence: patients with borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either 8 doses of mFOLFIRINOX (Arm 1) or 7 doses of mFOLFIRINOX plus hypofractionated radiotherapy (Arm 2)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate symptomatic adverse event (AE) rates using the Patient-Reported Outcomes Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (PRO-CTCAE) among patients with pancreatic cancer receiving neoadjuvant therapy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the frequency of symptomatic AEs, measured throughout the treatment period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: In trial A021501, conducted from December 31, 2016, to January 1, 2019, patients with borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of 126 patients, 96 initiated treatment and completed a baseline plus at least one post-baseline PRO-CTCAE assessment.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Decreased appetite was higher in Arm 2 than in Arm 1 (P = 0.0497).

Harms.evidence: Diarrhea and fatigue were the only symptomatic grade 3 or higher AEs identified in at least 10% of patients using CTCAE.
